I’ve made a feeble effort to  this one (anything I write hereon is just an iota of opinion as compared to the colossal body of s, articles, analysis and research done on this seminal work of Kafka). One feels that any amount of ing this multi-layered text is an exercise in productive futility. However….. Joseph K. on his thirtieth birthday finds himself accused of a crime whose details he is not allowed to know or ask. Thus, begins his spinning on a hamster wheel of a useless pursuit to emancipate himself from this quagmire-ish legal system; entailing pointless engagement with the advocate, fellow defendant, middle men, a relative, an artist and so on. ‘…..and sometimes one could not imagine that an average lifetimes experience would be enough to learn how to achieve anything.’The Court Chambers are situated in the attic of an impoverished tenement located in the poorest milieu of the city; this impenetrable and massive legal body well fed on the idea of guilt- with its endless hierarchy, vengeful disposition and its complete lack of understanding of human relationships has fortified itself with severe vigilance where court proceedings are not only kept secret from the public but also from the defendant. Any minor upheaval/chink in the armor of the system is brought back to its general equilibrium with some adjustment in its larger scheme of things that remain unchanged due to its maze like inter-relations. It is a legal system where the final acquittal is just a myth.‘No file gets lost; the court does not forget.’Joseph K’s impulsive rush to bring things to a conclusion leads him to commit a series of faux pas which eventually drag him to his doom. THE TRIAL is an astonishing reflection of any post-war/catastrophe experienced society which has a well guarded system functioning invincibly and unquestionably devoid of any internal mutiny. Any form of rebellion rising is fated to be nipped in its bud; for the system to claim its uncontested supremacy. This book will go in my stack of personal favorites! (Shriver explores the thoughtlessness behind the chowing down of the last morsel and looking forward to the next one (read: food), through fiction.)The book mulls over the concept of food and egregious obesity, an outcome of our lack of attention to ‘salivation, mastication and peristalsis’. This voluminous novel is captivatingly spun around the double murders committed by a student marinating in groveling poverty-in a hangdog fashion in a dingy cubby hole of a room shunning the worldly oppression/obligations of putting up a societal face in front of family and friends. The fertile yet deranged mind of Rakolnikov, the protagonist (read: anti-hero), pendulates between the self-styled morality of committing a crime and questioning the whole system-the law givers that define the act of transgressors as crime. The conundrums of feather-ruffling law-breakers who defy everything that the system obeying –ever multiplying conservatives are highlighted when Raskolnikov says:“I killed not a human but a principle!”Raskolnikov’s act of crime is rooted in his theory which questions the legality of a crime so committed wherein he positions a category of people (the genius) who are permitted everything. He bought into the whole student-arrogance-laced fancy where it’s not enough to just exist but to always believe in a sense of entitlement-ship where one feels one deserves more/better than the other person. This propounds his indifference or no remorse state after he kills the pawnbroker and her sister. The book talks deeply about ‘existential nihilism’ through its mouthpiece-Raskolnikov; especially when he rejects the virtue of “love your neighbor” and stresses on loving oneself first, conducting one’s own affairs which on the whole will result in general economic advancement. Sadism is another term that looms large in the book: reflected in vignettes of the unruly-drunk crowd beating an old mare to death; and in another instance when an affluent man boasts and normalizes domestic violence-“In all our seven years of marriage I used the whip only twice.”The book also mocks the empty “pride of the poor” who splurge their life’s hard earned income on the obligatory societal rites and rituals, simply ‘to make as good a showing as their neighbors and not be “criticized by them’.The novel reaches its crescendo when love becomes the veritable redeemer of Raskolnikov and the zest to live takes the place of ‘logic’- a heart troubled by theories. The book still remains a relevant one as it continues to rouse the minds of thinkers and readers alike on the polarized views of the left-wing and the right-wing on ‘self-interest’ and ‘criminality’; through the centering of the contemporary Russian society in its administrative heart- St. Petersburg- a town of ‘half-crazy people’. Larry Darrell, served as an aviator in WWI and scared by the horrors of war, wants to ‘loaf’ around exploring his existential crisis which takes him to Paris, Germany and India: ‘I want to find out why evil exists. Orbiting around the tumultuous lives of these characters is Elliott Templeton, a well-favored society magnet- “a party was the breath of his nostrils”. With his ‘bandbox’ elegance and ‘periwigged formality’ he becomes the quintessential charmer at elite dos and gatherings. Naipaul’s The Indian Trilogy)A litany of the ‘inexhaustible’ India…..A land of symbols, inaction and speechesWriter’s block and ennui beguiled Naipaul to visit India in 1962 for a year; like a beast of prey in pursuit of its quarry, Naipaul pens a savage diatribe on India who had failed to live up to its billing. The travelogue reads like a severe scrutiny and critique of India as a fading and decaying mythical land, a land that still romances and ‘rhapsodizes’ the glories of its ancient past. Like a cantankerous old relative he grumpily lands in Bombay where he performs a herculean task of getting a liquor transfer permit (read: prohibition-dry Bombay) from the paper-work obsessed offices. His short stay in Kashmir and Amarnath Yatra further enhances the acerbity of his narrative on India. ‘Eid- for the Kashmiri, the year’s solitary day of cleanliness, a penitential debauch of soap and water and itching new cloth.’Naipaul views the cultural hybridization of India and England of the Raj as ‘a violation’, a hilarious mixture of costumes and the flawed use of the misunderstood English language. This land of ruins is further tagged as a colonial country that was mainly harvesting politicians and speeches. Unlike E.M Forster’s and Kipling’s India, viewed with a more forgiving lens, Naipaul’s India remained the land of his childhood, an area of darkness which he was unable to ‘penetrate’. Naipaul, an impatient traveler, raises his word-whip on India-a behemoth of squalor and human decay. review: My entire reflection on this edifying piece of literary classic would produce but a poor reportage of my effort to  it. I shall forge forth noneMy entire reflection on this edifying piece of literary classic would produce but a poor reportage of my effort to  it. I shall forge forth nonetheless….Enter the dismal setting: Cocketown is a smoke fuming dragon of an industrial borough-‘an ugly citadel” of toxic airs and gases, houses its multitude of downtrodden operatives- generically tagged as “The Hands”. Dickens very theatrically portrays the rough and tumble of the mundane miseries of the injured pith and marrow of Coketown. The reader first meets the mind of Mr. Thomas Gradgrind, personified cannon ‘loaded to muzzle with facts’ and a knower of all the ‘Watersheds of the World’. Gradgrind, a man devoted to the faculty of reason, sits himself at Stone Lodge, a common landmark on the face of the country; where he holds his children hostage into bleak lecture rooms and statistical dens of facts away from the light of fancy. The parental roof becomes a “Jaundiced Jail”- a piece of machinery cutoff from all the fantastical interference.If this did not steer the delicate nerves of a bibliophile than enter: Mr. Josiah Bounderby (Gradgrind’s mental looking glass), the keeper of the Coketown, the detected ‘Bully of Humility’ and a never miss-er of chance to proclaim his old poverty. He reminds me of our elderly folks who never fail an opportunity to elaborate on the never-ending saga of their rise to fortune from their pits of humble beginnings. The third specimen: Slackbridge (read: a fugleman, a local union leader of the millers), with his Brutus-like oracular authority never fails to uplift the morale of the multitudes crushed under the despotic iron-foot of their industrial tyrants.The lone voice-Stephen Blackpool-refuses to shake hands with both the parties: the master and the union- thereby indicating the alarming side-effects of industrialization that questions the moral integrity of both the parties.The labyrinthine narrative further dismantles the fortified beliefs of these key characters and brings to surface the peripheral characters- Sissy Jupe (the daughter of a circus jester who disowns her due to his failing attempts to amuse his audience)and Jane (Gradgrind’s daughter who questions his father’s latent motives behind getting her married to Bounderby, thirty years his senior) . The book had an effect like -the blood-iron taste/smell that one feels/smells after holding an iron bar for a long time-on me. This work of fiction is relevant now more than ever-in the times of hammered uniform thinking, the times governed by single minded-staunch-one dimensional leaders and their ‘yes-men’. ...more

review: Woolf gives an insightful and well researched treatise on women as writers of fiction and the depiction of women in fiction; drawing heavily from the Woolf gives an insightful and well researched treatise on women as writers of fiction and the depiction of women in fiction; drawing heavily from the facts stated by historians about the condition of women in England in the Elizabethan era and how the lack of independent income and adequate personal space impeded their literary aspirations; how women scribbled in anonymity, hiding their work with a piece of blotting paper, most of their writing done in general sitting rooms …..Was such a state of mind most fit for the act of creation?Interestingly, Woolf links chastity to women writing under a pseudonym- Anonymity-because a woman’s intellectual outbursts should resist publicity (male dictum). She unveils the mind writing under great duress:‘Who shall measure the heat and violence of the poet’s heart when caught and tangled in a woman’s body?’Woolf was herself once barred from entering the library at Oxbridge because ladies were only allowed to enter its premise if consorted by a fellow of the college or equipped with a letter of introduction. This humiliation compels her to make a comparative inquiry into the well buttered educational institutions churning male scholars funded liberally by capitalists juxtaposed with impoverished women colleges lacking in basic amenities.Woolf also brings to light a colossal body of masculine musings on the inability of women to explore their intellectual faculties. “The history of man’s opposition to women’s emancipation is more interesting perhaps than the story of that emancipation itself.”Woolf impresses upon the importance of women having and making money- the ultimate emancipator of the mind to afford the luxury of thinking about the ways of the world as they are. It puts an end to hatred, the servile need for lowly couchings and flattering their male providers. A secure financial existence demystifies the bottomless creative possibilities for women that were earlier exclusively the domain of their male counterpart –a thoroughbred exercising his power and influence; ever eager to establish a superior seal while darkening the shine of his marginalized other. She urges women writers to have a liberated, well-nourished mind that is free to stretch itself by its own volition; and for women to acquire this mind and support their creative ambition they need to well bolster themselves with money and have a room ‘with a lock on the door’ to themselves. review: TARA WESTOVER-The Apache Woman-(Once- a Human Forklift)-(Unscathed by the Shear)This incredible memoir chronicles the off-kilter experience of Tara WeTARA WESTOVER-The Apache Woman-(Once- a Human Forklift)-(Unscathed by the Shear)This incredible memoir chronicles the off-kilter experience of Tara Westover’s childhood growing up on Buck’s Peak, Idaho with her inexorable family, a father (bipolar/schizophrenic) who distrusts any form of government establishment (read: agents of Illuminati), a mother (an uncertified midwife) who is an equal shareholder in her husband’s radical believes (End of days), and blends oils to heal any wound or cure diseases, Audrey (her meek and submissive sister), brothers Shawn (a sadist who resorts to violent outbursts like a cur), Richard, Tyler and Tony (her holy trinity)Mormonism breathed heavy in the Westover family (with an overarching patriarch determined to protect his seven children from the clutches of public schools, medicines and hospitals). Out of this junkyard laboring-metal scrapping-purlins hauling-feral horse breaking- brood, emerges a feisty girl who is a misfit, “whose rhythm is off, whose meter is set to the wrong tune”.WHAT WE WHISPERED AND WHAT WE SCREAMED FAITH BEFORE SAFETY: “We had been bruised and gashed and concussed, had our legs set on fire and our heads cut open.
